title: 113_s247
content:
The Act is titled the "Harriet Tubman National Historical Parks Act" and establishes the Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad National Historical Park in Maryland. The Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad National Historical Park is established in Maryland, with definitions for terms like historical park, map, Secretary, and State provided in the section. The Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad National Historical Park in Maryland will be established once enough land is acquired, and the Secretary will publish an official boundary map in the Federal Register. The official boundary map for the Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad National Historical Park will be available for public inspection. The purpose of the park is to preserve and interpret the historical, cultural, and natural resources related to Harriet Tubman and the Underground Railroad. The Secretary may acquire land within designated areas for the park through purchase, donation, or exchange. The boundary of the historical park will be adjusted upon land acquisition. The Secretary will administer the park in accordance with relevant laws and enter into an interagency agreement within a year of establishment. The Fish and Wildlife Service will allow the National Park Service to interpret historic resources related to Harriet Tubman within the Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge. The Secretary may also provide interpretive tours in Maryland counties outside the park boundary. Cooperative agreements can be made with the State, political subdivisions, colleges, and universities. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with various entities to mark, interpret, and restore historic resources related to Harriet Tubman and the Underground Railroad within the boundaries of the historical park, or to conduct research. Additionally, a joint visitor center may be designed, constructed, operated, and maintained on State-owned land through a cooperative agreement. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with entities to provide visitor facilities and office space for the historical park on State-owned land. The Federal share of costs for activities shall not exceed 50 percent, and the non-Federal share may be in the form of in-kind contributions or goods. The Secretary will prepare a general management plan for the historical park within 3 years of funds availability, in consultation with the State. Coordination with Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge and Harriet Tubman National Historical Park will be ensured. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the Harriet Tubman National Historical Park and the National Underground Railroad Network to Freedom. SEC. 3. Harriet Tubman National Historical Park in Auburn, New York. The Harriet Tubman National Historical Park in Auburn, New York is established as a unit of the National Park System. Key definitions include "historical park" referring to the Harriet Tubman National Historical Park, "Home" as The Harriet Tubman Home, Inc., "map" as the designated map for the park, "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, and "State" as the State of New York. The Harriet Tubman National Historical Park in Auburn, New York is part of the National Park System. The park will be established once enough land is acquired, and a notice will be published in the Federal Register. The park's boundaries will be defined on a map available for public inspection. The Harriet Tubman National Historical Park in Auburn, New York will include the Harriet Tubman Home, Tubman Home for the Aged, Thompson Memorial AME Zion Church, and associated land. The purpose is to preserve and interpret historical, cultural, and natural resources related to Harriet Tubman. The Secretary may acquire land within the designated areas for the park's administration. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with landowners within the historical park in Auburn, New York to mark, interpret, or restore historic resources related to Harriet Tubman. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with landowners in Auburn, New York related to Harriet Tubman's life. The agreement allows access to public portions of the land for historical park visitors and interpretation. Changes to the land require mutual agreement between the Secretary and the landowner. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with various entities to conduct research on Harriet Tubman's life. The Federal share of the total cost should not exceed 50 percent, and the non-Federal share can be in the form of in-kind contributions or goods/services. The Secretary must submit cooperative agreements involving religious property to the Attorney General for review. No agreement can take effect until the Attorney General confirms it complies with the Establishment Clause. Additionally, a General Management Plan must be developed within 3 years of funds being available for this section. The Secretary must prepare a general management plan for the historical park in coordination with other related parks and networks. Authorization of appropriations is provided, with a limit of $7,500,000 for financial assistance under subsection (c)(3). SEC. 4. OFFSET.

Amends the Water Resources Development Act of 1996 by reducing the authorized amount from $53,852,000 to $29,852,000.
